awd_titl_txt: Development and Application of Molecular Simulation Methods to Compute Bulk and Interfacial Properties of Ionic Liquids
awd_abstract_narration:
Jeffrey Errington of the State University of New York at Buffalo is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to carry out the development and application of molecular simulation methods to compute properties of ionic fluids at interfaces, e.g., where another fluid or the walls of a container is encountered. These places are particularly difficult for accurate computations compared to others away from interfaces.  Numerous current and emerging technologies such as supercapacitors (which store energy in small areas) and solar cells (which convert sunlight to electricity) contain ionic fluids, e.g., salts in which the ions move as liquids at room temperature.  In many cases, how well such devices perform their work depends on properties of the fluid in more than one place, i.e., both close to and far from containing walls. Development of a deeper fundamental understanding of the behavior of ionic fluids in the presence of surfaces would have a profound influence on the ability of scientists and engineers to improve device performance, design novel technologies, and harness the unique features of natural systems.  For example, information of this type may provide insight into how the chemistry of an ionic liquid or surface could be tuned to optimize the performance of a supercapacitor in energy storage, improve a coating placed on various materials, or facilitate development of a lens whose focus and other properties can be changed at will. Both graduate and undergraduate students are being trained in the areas of surface thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, and computer simulation. The principal investigator also participates in outreach at a local middle school.

The group studies two fundamental issues: (1) the temperature dependence of the interfacial properties (e.g., contact angle) of ionic fluids such as room temperature ionic liquids (RTILs), molten salts and charged colloids, and (2) the impact of small molecules, such as water and carbon dioxide, on the interfacial properties of RTILs. The temperature dependence of interfacial properties has received relatively little attention. Recent simulation results for model ionic fluids suggest that these fluids exhibit highly tunable temperature dependence, which could be exploited in the design of technological devices. Experiments provide contradictory views regarding how water impacts the surface tension of RTILs. In the present work, molecular simulation is used to resolve these discrepancies and provide a better understanding of the link between macroscopic interfacial properties and the manner in which molecules partition within these inhomogeneous systems. To facilitate the investigation of these issues, the group pursues two methodological advances: (1) an isothermal-isobaric version of the interface potential approach and (2) strategies for sampling mixtures of ionic liquids. The interface potential approach focuses on the surface excess free energy of a thin fluid film in contact with a substrate. The investigator's group has employed a grand canonical version of this approach for several years with success. However, application of this technique to complex systems is hindered by molecule transfers required within a grand canonical ensemble. The research team addresses this limitation via development of a version of the method that is implemented within the isothermal-isobaric ensemble. This advance allows one to both address complex systems and leverage popular molecular dynamics software to complete calculations.

por.por_cntn:
Numerous current and emerging technologies contain ionic fluids. Of particular interest are room temperature ionic liquids (RTILs). These are organic salts that are liquids at room temperature. They have many desirable features. For example, they are electrically conducting, possess low vapor pressure (do not escape into the atmosphere), and are tunable in the sense that many different cation and anion pairs can be combined. In many cases these fluids are brought into contact with one or more solid surfaces. Device performance can vary significantly with the bulk and interfacial properties of the fluid. It follows that the design of these applications benefits from fundamental knowledge regarding the relationship between microscopic substrate-fluid and fluid-fluid interactions within a system and the macroscopic properties it exhibits. Examples that illustrate the need for knowledge of how ionic liquids interact with a surface are numerous, and include the design of supercapacitors, solar cells, dispersants, gas handlers, coatings, variable lenses, and electronic paper. Information of this type provides insight into how the chemistry of an ionic liquid or substrate can be tuned to obtain a desired behavior. Unfortunately, a microscopic picture of ionic fluid interfacial behavior has been slow to develop. Molecular simulation provides an ideal tool for studying these systems. However, the use of molecular simulation to investigate ionic fluids at interfaces has been hindered by a lack of effective computational methods for studying such systems.

The goal of this project was to develop and apply molecular simulation methods that enable one to deduce the interfacial properties of ionic fluids. A key property of interest is the contact angle formed by a liquid droplet in contact with a solid surface. This property provides a quantitative measure of the extent to which a fluid spreads on a solid surface.  Such information is critical for the design of many industrial processes. Our aim was to develop methods that are broadly accessible to the science and engineering community. To that end, we focused on strategies that could be implemented with the use of commonly available molecular dynamics software packages. Examples include the LAMMPS Molecular Dynamics Simulator and the GROMACS simulation package. We successfully developed methods that leverage the so-called interface potential. This potential provides the free energy associated with pulling a surface away from a liquid (see Figure 1). Within our strategy, we employ molecular dynamics simulation to measure the force that the fluid exerts on the surface at multiple separation distances. Examples of this force curve for a common RTIL at three temperatures are provided in Figure 2. These force measurements are then used to construct the interface potential. As is illustrated in Figure 3, the drying coefficient is extracted from the interfacial potential curve. The drying coefficient is related to the contact angle via a simple expression. Therefore, the data from simulation enable one to deduce macroscopic properties of interest.

The methods were used to study the wetting behavior of model ionic fluids. We generated an interesting set of results detailing the temperature dependence of interfacial properties for model systems.  Data for the wetting temperature were unexpected.  The wetting temperature is associated with that point at which a fluid spreads evenly on a surface. At conditions away from the wetting point the fluid forms liquid lenses (beads up) on a surface. The trends we observed for model ionic fluids are qualitatively different than those for nonionic fluids. This unique behavior could provide the basis for novel sensor or other technologies. Further experimental and simulation studies are needed to better understand the wetting behavior of ionic fluids.

Advances from this project facilitate the use of molecular simulation as a practical tool for advancing fundamental knowledge regarding the wetting behavior of ionic liquids. Moreover, the tools developed in this project are general in nature, and therefore are expected to enhance the ability of the community to study the behaviors of many complex fluids.
